name: Simple API Gateway
description: Learn the basics: Route → Service. Your first Kong Gateway configuration.
learningObjectives: Expose a backend service through Kong
Test your first API gateway setup

explanation.overview: This is the simplest Kong Gateway pattern. You're creating a gateway that forwards requests from clients to a backend service. Think of it like a smart router for your API.

steps.title: Create a Service
steps.description: A Service in Kong represents your backend API. In this example, we're using HTTPBin (a public testing service at httpbin.org). In production, this would be your actual backend like users-api.internal:8080.
steps.tip: Always use HTTPS for production services to ensure secure communication between Kong and your backend.

steps.title: Create a Route
steps.description: A Route defines how clients access your service. This route matches any request to the path /api. When Kong receives a request to http://kong:8000/api, it knows to forward it to the HTTPBin service.
steps.tip: Routes can match on paths, methods, hosts, or headers. You can be very specific about what traffic gets routed where.

steps.title: Connect Route to Service
steps.description: This connection tells Kong: 'When a request matches this route, forward it to this service.' This is the core of Kong's request routing.
steps.tip: Every Route MUST connect to exactly one Service. This is a strict Kong requirement.

keyTakeaways: Routes define HOW clients access your APIs (matching rules)
Services define WHERE requests should be forwarded (backend location)
The Route → Service connection is mandatory and must be 1:1
Kong acts as a smart proxy, forwarding matched requests to your backend

testInstructions:
After deploying this configuration:

1. Send a test request:
   curl http://localhost:8000/api/get

2. You should receive a JSON response from HTTPBin showing your request details.

3. Try different methods:
   curl -X POST http://localhost:8000/api/post

If you get a response, congratulations! Your first Kong Gateway is working.

commonMistakes.fix: Always specify a valid backend host (hostname or IP address)
commonMistakes.explanation: Kong needs to know where to forward requests. Without a host, the service won't work.

commonMistakes.mistake: Forgetting to connect Route to Service
commonMistakes.fix: Drag a connection from the Route node to the Service node
commonMistakes.explanation: Routes must be connected to services. An unconnected route won't forward any traffic.

commonMistakes.fix: Set strip_path to false if you want to preserve the original path
commonMistakes.explanation: If strip_path is true, Kong removes /api from the path before forwarding. Usually you want to keep it.
